Designing highly efficient and stable catalysts is vital for large-scale manufacturing of 1,4-butenediol via continuous-flow semi-hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol. Herein, Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalysts are investigated in the semi-hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol. Both the Ptδ−-Znδ+ structure and the decreased Pt surface density caused by Zn decoration profoundly affect the adsorption structures and bonding strength of the reactants and intermediates, thus leading to a favorable hydrogenation property. The activation energy over PtZn0.5/CeO2 is 42.8 kJ mol−1, which is lower than 56.6 kJ mol−1 over Pt/CeO2 catalyst. The PtZn0.5/CeO2 achieves the highest 1,4-butenediol yield (85%) under mild conditions and stability in the long-term reaction (100 h). This stems from the proper spatial arrangement of Ptδ− active sites leading to a weak π-bonding mode toward CC adsorption, rather than strong di-σ adsorption at successive Pt sites. It provides fundamental guidelines for designing Pt-based catalysts with high performance for the selective hydrogenation of alkynols. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Selective hydrogenation 1 4-butynediol PtZn alloy Electronic effect Geometric structure Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Selective catalytic hydrogenation of alkynols to enols is one of the most important processes in fine chemical industries. Enols are intermediates in the manufacture of many agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, dyes, and pigments [1]. Among the enols, 1,4-butenediol (BED) produced by the reduction of 1,4-butynediol (BYD) is a key compound for the production of endosulfan, vitamins A and B6, tetrahydrofuran, γ-butyrolactone, polyurethanes, n-methyl pyrrolidone, as well as for different bactericides [2,3]. It also has wide-ranging applications in the paper and textile industries and resin manufacture [4]. Generally, the hydrogenation reaction network of BYD may proceed by a complex set of parallel and consecutive reactions [5]. Due to the presence of carbon-carbon triple and hydroxy functional groups, BYD is semi-hydrogenated to produce BED first. However, the deep hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, and isomerization reactions inevitably occur, eventually producing by-products including 1,4-butanediol (BAD), 2-hydroxytetrahydrofuran (HTHF), and n-butanol (BOL) [6]. Therefore, for achieving the high yield of BED, it is vital to synthesizing the high-efficient, unique selective, and stable catalysts for the aqueous phase hydrogenation of BYD in a continuous-flow reactor. In general, the selective hydrogenation of alkynols to enols is achieved over the supported noble metal-based catalysts [7]. However, supported monometallic catalysts often have serious selectivity problems [8]. To fabricate efficient selective hydrogenation catalysts, many strategies have been developed to tune the electronic or geometric properties of active sites, such as introducing second metals (e.g., Pb [9], Bi [10,11], Fe [12], Si [13], Cs [14], and Cu [15]), tailoring the metal-support interactions (e.g., ZnO [16,17], SiC [18], ZIF-8 [19], poly(4-vinylpyridine) [20], bovine-bone powder [21], and bacterial biomass [22]), and employing modifiers (e.g., quinoline [15], pyridine [23], and Schiff-base [24]). Among these strategies, the introduction of a second metal has been proven to be a simple and effective way to modify and isolate the active sites, which is widely used in metal-based catalysts, and therefore achieved high enols selectivity. Recently, the combination of Pt with Zn to form alloys or intermetallic compounds play a key role in the selective hydrogenation of substrates with more than one unsaturated bond [25–28]. Galloway et al. suggested that the change of electronic properties of Pt in PtZn alloy hindered the adsorption of the CC double bond during crotonaldehyde hydrogenation [27]. Due to the active-sites isolation and electronic modification of Zn, the PtZn catalyst also showed significantly improved activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene [28]. Therefore, the Zn species decorated Pt active site may boost the selective hydrogenation properties. However, there are few reports on the PtZn alloys or intermetallic compounds for the semi-hydrogenation of alkynols to enols. Additionally, the rational design of a highly selective catalyst hinges on the nature of the support. Combining metallic nanoparticles with oxide supports improves the dispersion of the active phase, promotes thermal stability, and may disrupt the chemisorption potential. The commonly studied supports for selective hydrogenation of alkynols are Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2. An emerging support for this reaction is CeO2, which has the potential to anchor the metallic nanoparticles via the creation of O vacancies on the oxide surface. In addition, CeO2 shows higher water resistance stability than other supports, which will enhance the stability of catalysts, especially the hydrothermal stability, for the continuous-flow hydrogenation of alkynols to enols. In this work, a series of Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalysts are prepared by the reactive metal-metal oxide interaction strategy and investigated in the aqueous phase continuous-flow hydrogenation of BYD. Several catalyst characterization techniques are carried out to determine the effect of Zn on the electronic and geometric structures of the Pt phase. Compared to the Pt/CeO2 as a reference catalyst, PtZnx/CeO2 catalyst displays an exceptional selectivity to BED and a higher TOF. Combined reaction kinetic tests and in situ infrared characterizations results reveal that the local electron-rich Pt surrounded by Zn atoms could facilitate the BYD semi-hydrogenation route by reducing the reactant activation energy as well as inhibiting the over-hydrogenation route via changing the adsorption strength and conformation of BED. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and preparation of catalysts All aqueous solutions were prepared with deionized water. All raw materials were purchased from commercial corporations and used without further purification. H2PtCl6 (Macklin, >98 wt%) and ZnCl2 (Macklin, >99.95 wt%) were used as Pt and Zn precursors, respectively. Citric acid and precursor Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O were purchased from Tianjin Kemiou and Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, respectively. Allyl alcohol and propargyl alcohol were purchased from Chengdu Huafu Inc. 1,4-butynediol (>98 wt%) and 1,2-propanediol were purchased from Macklin and Tianjin Guangfu Inc, respectively. The CeO2 support was synthesized by the citric acid complex process. Firstly, the aqueous solution of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (0.5 mol L−1) was added to the aqueous solution of citric acid (1.5 mol L−1) at 60 °C with stirring for 1 h. Then, water was removed by a rotary evaporator and the leftover obtained was dried overnight at 110 °C. After that, the solid was roasted at 300 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in 50 vol% O2/Ar by tube furnace. All catalysts were prepared by impregnation with controlling the theoretical loading of Pt at 1%. Typically, 2 g of CeO2 and 6.667 mL of H2PtCl6 solution with a concentration of 6.3 mg mL−1 were added into round bottom flasks containing 25 mL of deionized water. Then a certain ZnCl2 solution with a concentration of 6 mg mL−1 was added to the flask. The mixed solution was macerated continuously for 12 h at room temperature with stirring. Then the water was removed by a rotary evaporator and the resulting solids were dried overnight in an oven at 110 °C. Finally, the solid was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h in 50 vol% O2/Ar and then reduced at 600 °C for 2 h in 50 vol% H2/Ar. The heating rate for both the calcination as well as the reduction process was 5 °C/min. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The metal content was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES: Thermo Fisher iCAP PRO). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses of samples were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-RB diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα1 monochromatized radiation source with a scanning rate of 10 °/min. The BET surface area and pore structure of samples were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements on a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ automated gas sorption analyzer. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and CO chemisorption (CO-Chem) were performed on AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer with a thermal conductivity detector. A stoichiometry of CO: Pt = 1:1 was assumed to estimate the number of active meter sites of the catalyst and determine the TOF value. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and elemental mapping were obtained by adopting the aberration-corrected microscope operating at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were conducted on Thermo Escalab Xi+ . Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was acquired using a Thermo Nicolet i50 FTIR spectrometer with a Praying Mantis DRIFTS reactor (Harrick Scientific). Each spectrum was collected after 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1 from 650 to 4000 cm−1. Pt/CeO2 and PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalysts loaded on the DRIFTS reactor were in situ reduced at 600 °C for 2 h in 10 vol% H2/Ar with the flow rate of 40 sccm, and then cooled down to the target temperature in Ar for 10 min, the spectra were recorded as a background under the Ar atmosphere. In the CO-DRIFTS experiment, 10 vol% CO/He was introduced into the cell at 10 mL/min for 40 min at 20 °C to reach an equilibrium state. The gas-phase CO was then purged out of the cell under 40 sccm Ar flow for 30 min before collecting spectra of the adsorbed CO on the surfaces. The adsorption strength of CO was qualitatively studied by monitoring the peak intensity change while heating the sample in the cell at 1 °C/min to 120 °C. In the propargyl alcohol temperature-programmed hydrogenation experiment, propargyl alcohol under the action of Ar as carrier gas was fed into the system until that the adsorption was saturated at 30 °C. After removing any physisorbed and gas-phase propargyl alcohol through purging with Ar, the spectra of intermediate products on the surface reaction in the 10 vol% H2/Ar flow with a heating rate programmed of 1 °C/min were captured. In the allyl alcohol temperature-programmed desorption experiment, allyl alcohol under the action of Ar as carrier gas was fed into the system until that the adsorption was saturated at 30 °C. After removing any physisorbed and gas-phase allyl alcohol through purging with Ar, the spectra of allyl alcohol on the surface of the samples were collected continuously in an Ar atmosphere with a heating rate of 1 °C/min to 130 °C. 2.3 Selective hydrogenation of BYD in continuous-flow reactor In a typical hydrogenation experiment, 0.05 g of the as-prepared catalyst with a particle size of 0.15 mm (The sample particle was passed through a 100-mesh sieve.) diluted with quartz to 5 mL was filled into a fixed bed reactor. The schematic of the fixed bed reactor system is shown in Fig. S1. After replacing the air inside the reactor with H2, the sample was reduced at 600 °C with 40 sccm H2 flow for 2 h. The liquid reactant consisted of 1 wt% BYD aqueous solution and 1 wt% 1,2-propanediol (as internal standard) was pumped into the reactor to carry out the hydrogenation reaction when controlling the reaction temperature at 80 °C, the hydrogen pressure at 1 MPa, and the H2/liquid reactant volume flow rate ratio of 300 with the reactant contact times of 217, 107, 72, 43, and 22 gcat h mol−1, respectively (The detail is shown in Table S1). The mass transfer limitation over PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts was calculated, as shown in Supplementary Material. The products were quantitatively evaluated via gas chromatography (Bruker 450-GC) equipped with a capillary column FFAP (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) and an FID detector. Qualitative identification of products was achieved by GC-MS (Agilent 5977 A/7890B). To guarantee the data's accuracy and reproducibility, each experiment was performed two times in parallel and the sample was analyzed three times using gas chromatography. The contact time, conversion (X) of BYD, selectivity (Si) of products, and dispersion of Pt metal (DPt) were defined as follows: (1) Contact time (gcat h mol−1) = mcat/(F×60) (2) X = (n0 – nt)/n0×100% (3) Si = ni/Σni×100% (4) DPt = (QCO/1)/(PPt/MPt)×100% where mcat (g) was the mass of the catalyst, and F (mol/min) was the molar flow rate of the reactant, n0 and nt assigned to the mole of reactant in the feed and product, respectively, ni attributed to the mole of product i and Σni are the total moles of products, QCO (mol/g) was the CO adsorption quantity measured by CO-Chem, the relative atomic mass of Pt (MPt) was 195.09, stoichiometry factor was 1, PPt was the percent of Pt metal mass measured by ICP-OES. For understanding the intrinsic catalytic activity of catalysts, the turnover frequency (TOF) was evaluated by the following formula: (5) TOF(h−1) = (F × 60 × X)/(ntotal × DPt) Where ntotal was the mole of Pt metal in the catalyst. The standard deviation of TOF is based on the data from five conditions in which the conversion is below 30%. The activation energy and its standard deviation are derived from a linear fit to the Arrhenius curve. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties The XRD patterns of all reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. In all cases, the peaks at ca. 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, and 56.3° can be ascribed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) plane of the fluorite cubic structure of CeO2 (JCPDS # 34–0394). There are no Pt or PtZn alloy diffraction peaks observed for all catalysts, possibly due to the low loading amount, small crystalline size, and good dispersion of metal phase on the support. In the samples with high Zn loadings, some new diffraction peaks are observed near the main diffraction peak of CeO2, which may be attributed to the formation of a small amount of CeOx. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of all samples are illustrated in Fig. 2. The morpho structural properties, such as the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter for all samples, are listed and compared in Table 1. The results indicate that CeO2 has the highest specific surface area of 106 m2 g−1, and the specific surface area of PtZnx/CeO2 samples decreases from 101 m2 g−1 to 87 m2 g−1 with increasing Zn loadings. All samples have a pore volume of ca. 0.2 cm3 g−1. The measured average pore diameter distribution for all samples is in the range of 4–5 nm, indicating the presence of mesoporous properties. To investigate the phases and morphology of catalysts in detail, the Pt/CeO2 and PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalysts are further characterized by TEM. As shown in Figs. 3a and 3b, the Pt nanoparticles may disperse on the CeO2 support highly and the region with a lattice spacing of 0.209 nm may be attributed to the metallic Pt. For the TEM images of PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst (as shown in Figs. 3c and 3d), three kinds of periodicities of lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.320 nm, 0.276 nm, and 0.196 nm index to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of CeO2, respectively. There are no obvious PtZn particles observed, which may be attributed that the formed PtZn alloys with ultrasmall particle size are dispersed uniformly on the catalyst surface of CeO2. The elemental mapping images (Figs. 3e and 3 f) confirm the uniform distribution of Pt, Zn, Ce, and O elements within the PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst. The H2-TPR technique permits not only to characterize the reduction temperature of the catalyst but also elucidate the role of Zn in the reduction process. Fig. 4a shows the H2-TPR profiles of Pt/CeO2 and PtZnx/CeO2 samples. According to peak positions, the reducible PtOx species could be separated into two types [29]. The peaks in the range of 175–240 °C are ascribed to PtO species, and the peaks located at 380 °C can be attributed to the PtO2 phase. The PtOx reduction peak shifted toward a higher temperature with increasing Zn loadings. This finding reveals that the addition of Zn suppresses the reduction of Pt species, and reflects the extensive interaction between Zn modifiers and Pt components. Specifically, after the PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts are reduced at high temperature, there is close contact between the zero-valent Pt and Zn atoms, and the reduced Zn diffused from the surface into Pt nanoparticles to form PtZn alloy. The H2-TPD technique is used to determine the binding energy of hydrogen molecules on catalysts. Fig. 4b shows H2-TPD curves of the Pt/CeO2 and PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts. Compared with Pt/CeO2, the PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts have higher hydrogen desorption capacity and lower hydrogen desorption temperature. This is evidence that Pt alloying with Zn completely changes the surface properties of the original Pt in terms of hydrogen adsorption. The scattered Pt sites in PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts lead to a larger hydrogen adsorption capacity while the electron-rich Pt sites lead to easier hydrogen desorption [30], which is consistent with the results obtained from theoretical calculations [31]. Hydrogen is more easily activated on PtZnx/CeO2 catalyst, thus helping to improve the hydrogenation activity [30]. XPS characterization was conducted to investigate the chemical states of the Pt species. The XPS spectra of Pt 4 f for all catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. The binding energy values of the peaks on the spectra are given in Table S2. The binding energy values of principal peaks point to the existence of Pt and PtOx species [29,32]. A significant amount of PtOx species is present in the catalysts which increase from PtZn0.5/CeO2 to PtZn3/CeO2. Combined with the analysis of H2-TPR characterization, it can be speculated that the extent of PtOx reduction is dominated by the ZnO masking effect but not the reduction-promoting effect due to the presentation of electropositive metal Zn. According to Table S2, the Pt 4f 5/2 binding energy for the reduced Pt/CeO2 catalyst is at 74.8 eV, which is ascribed to Pt. However, in the case of the PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts, the binding energy decreases to ca. 74.5 eV, which indicates the formation of the PtZn alloy phase [33]. These phenomena indicate that Pt electronic states are modified by Zn via electron transfer from Zn to Pt atoms, in agreement with previous reports [34–37]. 3.2 Continuous-flow selective hydrogenation of BYD over PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts Fig. 6a shows the BYD conversion and products distribution over Pt/CeO2 and PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts under the same reaction conditions. The yield of BED follows the sequence: PtZn0.5/CeO2 > PtZn/CeO2 > PtZn2/CeO2 > PtZn3/CeO2 > Pt/CeO2. The addition of a small amount of Zn can greatly improve the yield of BED, but the continued addition of Zn has little effect on the improvement of BED yield but decreases the catalytic activity. The conversion decreases with the increase of Zn content can be ascribed to a lesser number of active sites on the modified catalysts due to the partial Pt surface coverage by Zn, which is demonstrated by the CO-Chem result that the adsorption capacity of CO decreases gradually with the increase of Zn addition (Table 1). The same phenomenon of noble metal masking due to the addition of excess second metal is also observed in the Pd-In system [38]. Fig. 6b shows the variations in BED selectivity with conversion in the hydrogenation of BYD over Pt/CeO2 and PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts. Monometallic Pt/CeO2 has good BED selectivity only at low BYD conversion, and the BED selectivity decreases significantly with increasing conversion. The bimetallic PtZnx/CeO2 catalyst shows superior and stable BED selectivity (above 85%). Over hydrogenation of BED occurs only when the conversion of BYD is nearly 100%. The products distribution of the BYD hydrogenation over Pt/CeO2 and PtZn0.5/CeO2 are compared, as shown in Fig. 7. The BED yield shows a volcano-type distribution over the Pt/CeO2 catalyst, and the yield of BAD and HTHF gradually increases with increasing contact time. However, the BED yield is higher than that of the Pt/CeO2 catalyst at the same contact time over the PtZn0.5/CeO2 bimetallic catalyst and remains at a higher level at longer contact times. Similar trends in product distribution are also found for several other bimetallic catalysts (Fig. S2). The original catalytic functions of Pt are greatly modified as a result of the formation of the PtZn alloy. The effects of reaction temperatures and H2 pressures on the catalytic performances over PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst are also explored, and the results are shown in Fig. S3. The selective hydrogenation of BYD to BED is suitable under mild conditions (1 MPa and 80 °C). Although the conversion of BYD is boosted under hard conditions, the target product (BED) is also prone to isomerization and over-hydrogenation at high temperatures and high H2 pressure. As a comparison, the hydrogenation of BYD over PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst is also evaluated in a batch reactor (The detail is shown in Supplementary Material). As shown in Fig. S4, the PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst presents high efficiency in the selectivity hydrogenation of BYD to BED. The selectivity to BED remains at a high level (>82%) throughout the reaction process. Intrinsic activity on a per-site basis in terms of the turnover frequency (TOF) offers a fair measure, by which to compare catalysts with different compositions and structures [39]. Considering the existence of the CO bridge adsorption site (Fig. 9a), the calculated TOF value of the Pt/CeO2 catalyst is higher than the actual value. Even so, the TOF value of the PtZn0.5/CeO2 is still higher than that of the Pt/CeO2 catalyst, the PtZn/CeO2, PtZn2/CeO2, and PtZn3/CeO2 catalysts show almost two times higher TOF compared to the Pt/CeO2 catalyst under the same conditions (Table 1). The improved TOF value originates from the unique isolated Ptδ- structure induced by Zn (as confirmed by XPS results), which facilitates the desorption of BED as opposed to over-hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis. Monitoring the reaction profiles and analyzing the reaction kinetics are very useful for illuminating the mechanistic details [40]. Fig. 8a shows that the BYD consumption rate (-ln(1-X)) is linearly related to the contact time. It can be an inference that the BYD hydrogenation over PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts is a pseudo-first-order reaction. The rate constant for the Pt/CeO2, PtZn0.5/CeO2, PtZn/CeO2, PtZn2/CeO2, PtZn3/CeO2 catalysts is 0.24 s−1, 0.40 s−1, 0.43 s−1, 0.25 s−1, and 0.36 s−1, respectively. This result further confirms that the modification of Pt by a trace of Zn species boosts the hydrogenation activity due to the formation of a unique isolated Ptδ- structure. Fig. 8b shows the Arrhenius plots of Pt/CeO2 and PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts. The activation energy data of catalysts are listed in Table 1. Although the excess Zn in the catalyst leads to the blocking of active Pt sites and lower activity per gram, the apparent activation energy of the exposed sites over PtZnx/CeO2 is as lower than Pt/CeO2 catalyst. The PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst has the lowest hydrogenation activation energy (42.8 KJ mol−1), which is lower than 56.6 KJ mol−1 over Pt/CeO2 catalyst. Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalyst can boost the selective hydrogenation of BYD in continuous-flow reactor. 3.3 Possible reaction mechanism of selective hydrogenation of BYD over PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst DRIFTS with CO as a probing molecule provides key information about the molecular adsorption behavior on the surface of catalysts [41]. As shown in Fig. 9a. The Pt/CeO2 exhibits both linearly adsorbed CO (band at 2075 and 2025 cm−1) and bridged adsorbed CO (band at 1810 cm−1) [42]. For the PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst, however, the IR spectrum is dominated by the linear bound CO (band at 2069 and 2013 cm−1) while the bridge bound CO (band between 1750 and 1850 cm−1) is a small feature [43]. The shift in the CO binding mode suggests that Zn breaks the Pt ensembles and creates isolated Pt sites binding CO linearly, which is in agreement with the previous reports [36]. In particular, there is a red-shift of the CO stretching frequency for PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst compared to Pt/CeO2 catalyst (from 2075 cm−1 to 2069 cm−1), indicating that the electron density of metallic Pt is increased [28,44], which further suggests the formation of PtZn alloy, in agreement with the observation of the XPS results. This also matches well with the H2-TPD analysis (Fig. 4b), with a greater desorbed amount of H2 from the site-isolated PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts than that of Pt/CeO2 catalyst. The time-dependent evolution of the CO-DRIFTS results for Pt/CeO2 and PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. S5, the intensity of the CO adsorption peak gradually decreases during the programmed ramp-up starting at 70 min Fig. 9b shows the temperature-dependent intensity of the CO linear adsorption peak. In the process of temperature-programmed starting at 20 ℃, the intensity of CO linear adsorption peak of PtZn0.5/CeO2 sample decreases more obviously than that of Pt/CeO2, marking a significantly lower adsorption strength of CO on the PtZn alloy. The weak CO adsorption on PtZn compared with Pt surfaces could leave more sites for BYD and H2 adsorption and facilitate the generation and desorption of BED. Due to the symmetry of BYD and BED molecular structures, the infrared absorption peak intensity of unsaturated bond stretching vibration is very weak, as shown in Fig. S6. As a result, propargyl alcohol and allyl alcohol are employed as model molecules to carry out relevant in situ infrared studies. In-situ temperature-programmed hydrogenation DRIFTS of propargyl alcohol collected over Pt/CeO2 and PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Figs. 10a and 10b. The intensity bands between the regions of 3700–3200, 3000–2700, and 2140–2100 cm−1 are observed owing to O-H and saturated C-H vibrations, as well as unsaturated C ≡ C vibrations of propargyl alcohol [45]. With the introduction of H2 for both catalysts, the band intensity in the range of 2140–2100 cm−1 reduces rapidly, while vibration peaks attributed to the CC of allyl alcohol appeared in the region of 1693–1682 cm−1. The above phenomena are consistent with the catalytic evaluation, that is, the main product of the reaction is BED whether on Pt/CeO2 or PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalysts. In-situ temperature-programmed desorption DRIFTS of allyl alcohol collected over Pt/CeO2 and PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Figs. 10c and 10d. The intensity of the CC group stretching vibration peak (1645 cm−1) of chemisorbed propyl alcohol gradually decreases with increasing temperature, while a new absorption peak appears at 1682 cm−1, which may be attributed to the CC group stretching vibration peak of gas-phase propyl alcohol after desorption from the catalyst surface. On the PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst, the chemisorbed CC bond peak almost disappears when the temperature is increased to 110 ℃, while on the Pt/CeO2 catalyst, the absorption peak still exists when the temperature is increased to 130 ℃. These results demonstrate that the adsorption of the CC group is suppressed significantly on PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst. Based on the above results, we speculate that the appropriate spatial arrangement of Ptδ- active sites in the PtZn alloy may lead to a weak π-bonding mode toward CC adsorption rather than strong di-σ adsorption at successive Pt sites as shown in Fig. 11, which offers the possibility for desorption of BED before being deeply hydrogenated [46,47]. 3.4 The stability testing of PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst The time course of BYD hydrogenation over the PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 12. The conversion of BYD increases from 92% at the beginning to 99% in the end, which may be the result of the re-exposure of Pt sites due to the partial shedding of Zn from the catalyst surface. However, the selectivity to BED is always maintained at a stable level (ca. 85%) over the 100 h test time. The results show that the PtZn0.5/CeO2 is a promising catalyst for selective hydrogenation of BYD in a continuous-flow reactor, which can be of high importance in fine-chemical synthesis industries. 4 Conclusions The Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalysts are investigated in the selective hydrogenation of BYD in a continuous-flow reactor. Compared with the catalytic performance of the Pt/CeO2 catalyst, both the catalytic activity and the selectivity to BED are boosted over PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst. The highest BED yield (85%) is achieved over PtZn0.5/CeO2 catalyst at 1 MPa and 80 °C with a contact time of 72 gcat h mol−1. The dispersion of Ptδ− species as a result of the formation of PtZn alloy is the key factor for high selectivity to BED, high TOF, and low activation energy in the hydrogenation of BYD. The appropriate spatial arrangement of isolated Ptδ− active sites in the PtZn alloy changes the adsorption mode of BED from strong di-σ-bonding at continuous Pt-Pt sites to weak π-bonding, which promotes the desorption of BED from the surface of the catalyst, inhibiting its over hydrogenation. Additionally, the Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalyst shows long-term stability in the continuous-flow selective hydrogenation of BYD to BED. This work provides fundamental guidelines for the design and understanding of Pt-based catalysts with high performance for the selective hydrogenation of alkynols and reveals once more the potential applications of PtZn alloy in selective hydrogenation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Designing highly efficient and stable catalysts is vital for large-scale manufacturing of 1,4-butenediol via continuous-flow semi-hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol. Herein, Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalysts are investigated in the semi-hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol. Both the Ptδ−-Znδ+ structure and the decreased Pt surface density caused by Zn decoration profoundly affect the adsorption structures and bonding strength of the reactants and intermediates, thus leading to a favorable hydrogenation property. The activation energy over PtZn0.5/CeO2 is 42.8 kJ mol−1, which is lower than 56.6 kJ mol−1 over Pt/CeO2 catalyst. The PtZn0.5/CeO2 achieves the highest 1,4-butenediol yield (85%) under mild conditions and stability in the long-term reaction (100 h). This stems from the proper spatial arrangement of Ptδ− active sites leading to a weak π-bonding mode toward CC adsorption, rather than strong di-σ adsorption at successive Pt sites. It provides fundamental guidelines for designing Pt-based catalysts with high performance for the selective hydrogenation of alkynols.
coredata.dc:title: Zn species decorated Pt/CeO2 catalysts for selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol in continuous-flow reactor
